title: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe pleads for release so she can see daughter start school
text:

The British-Iranian woman jailed in Tehran has pleaded to be released so she can see five-year-old daughter start school in the UK.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe has been visited in prison in the Iranian capital by Gabriella at least once a week for the past three years.

But now the youngster is heading back to enrol in a London primary school before Christmas.

Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe was arrested in April 2016 and sentenced to five years in jail after being accused of spying, which she vehemently denies.

In a letter smuggled out of jail she wrote: “I have no hope or motivation after my baby goes.

“There is no measure to my pain. In the near future, my baby will leave me to go to her father and start school in the UK.

"It will be a daunting trip for her travelling and me left behind.

(Image: Getty)

(Image: EPA-EFE/REX)

“And the authorities who hold me will watch on, unmoved at the injustice of separation."

Her fight for freedom has seen her endure hunger strikes and solitary confinement amid a diplomatic row.

Her family agreed that Gabriella should return to the UK to start the school year in September but postponed the decision after Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe was taken to a psychiatric hospital.

She was returned to prison after a week but not permitted phone calls with her husband, Richard Ratcliffe.

(Image: The Free Nazanin campaign)

(Image: PA)

He said his wife is hoping for a last minute release to enable her to come home with Gabriella. “I don’t think she’s expecting it though,” he said.

He added: “Gabriella has been a lifeline for Nazanin. That’s the hardest part. It will feel like abandonment.”

Gabriella has lived with her grandparents in Tehran since April 2016.

In a much-criticised error, PM Boris Johnson said in 2017 that she was in Iran “teaching people journalism” – despite her family saying she was visit relatives.
